newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks tumble 1.29 pct on official warning.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks tumble 1.29 pct on official warning.

text.p: Taiwan share prices closed sharply lower on Monday, as investors heeding a central bank warning about the market's sizzling rally locked in profits in the heavily weighted financial sector, brokers said.
The index ended down 103.26 points or 1.29 percent at 7,880.45 points, just above its morning low of 7,879.86.
Turnover was a hectic T$105.079 billion.
The most heavily weighted financials plunged 3.16 percent, with Huan Nan Bank down T$9 to close at T$145, and Cathay Life Insurance falling T$7 to T$180.
The cement and construction sectors dropped 1.15 percent and 1.05 percent, respectively, with Southeast Cement sliding T$1.20 at T$30.40.

"The central bank's warning on Saturday was the main reason pulling down the closely watched financial issues, which often react swiftly to any comments by the central bank," said Jardine Fleming fund manager George Hou. Hou said the central bank hopes market turnover will not become too large.
Central bank deputy governor Hsu Chia-tung said on Saturday that individual investors should exercise caution in a big rally that added more than 1,000 points in January and February.
Other stock analysts said share prices would remain on a correction basis in the near term because of Hsu's comment.
Brokers said they expected a bearish trend as long as the discouraging news from the central bank lingers.
For Tuesday, a 7,500-7,900 trading range was seen.
